column2: FOREMAN: NO. 6?
column3: NO. 6: Not guilty.
column4: FOREMAN: NO. 7?
column5: NO. 7: Guilty.
column6: GUARD: Is there anything wrong, gentlemen? I heard some noise.
column7: FOREMAN: NO. 8?

column2: NO.8: Not guilty.
column3: FOREMAN: NO. 9?
column4: NO.9: Not guilty. .
column5: FOREMAN: NO. 10?
column6: NO. 10: Guilty.
column7: NO. 3: What do you mean? It's just common sense.

column2: FOREMAN: NO.11?
column3: NO.11: Not guilty.
column4: FOREMAN: NO. 12?
column5: NO.12: Guilty.
column6: NO. 11: I beg your pardon. Maybe you don't understand the term "reasonable doubt.”
column7: NO.4: Six to six.

column2: NO.10 (mad) I’ll tell you something. The crime is being committed right in this room.
column3: FOREMAN: The vote is six to six.
column4:
NO. 3: I'm ready to walk into court right now and declare a hung jury. There's no point in this going on any
more.
column5: NO. 7: I go for that, too. Let's take it in to the judge and let the kid take his chances with twelve other guys.
column6: [NO. 4 sits silently. NO. 3 looks at him, and then he strides over to NO. 8]
column7: NO. 5: (to NO. 7). You mean you still don't think there's room for reasonable doubt?

column2: NO. 7: No, I don't.
column3: NO. 11: I beg your pardon. Maybe you don't understand the term "reasonable doubt.”
column4:
NO. 7: (angry). What do you mean I don't understand it? Who do you think you are to talk to me like that? (To
all) How do you like this guy? He comes over here running for his life, and before he can even take a big breath
he's telling us how to run the show. The arrogance of him!
column5: NO. 5: (to NO. 7). Wait a second. Nobody around here's asking where you came from.
column6: NO. 7: I was born right here.
column7: GUARD: Is there anything wrong, gentlemen? I heard some noise.

column2:
NO. 5: Or where your father came from. (He looks at NO. 7, who doesn't answer but looks away.) Maybe it
wouldn't hurt us to take a few tips from people who come running here! Maybe they learned something we don't
know. We're not so perfect!
column3: NO. 11: Please—I am used to this. It's all right. Thank you.
column4: NO.5: It's not all right!
column5: NO. 7: Okay, okay, I apologize. Is that what you want?
column6: NO. 5: That's what I want.
column7:
[NO. 8 puts his hand on NO. 9's arm and stops him. Somehow his touch and his gentle expression calm the old
man. He draws a deep breath and relaxes.]

column2: FOREMAN: All right. Let's stop the arguing. Who's got something constructive to say?
column3:
NO.2: (hesitantly). Well, something's been bothering me a little . . . this whole business about the stab wound
and how it was made, the downward angle of it, you know?
column4: NO. 3: Don't tell me we're gonna start that. They went over it and over it in court.
column5:
NO. 2: I know they did—but I don't go along with it. The boy is five feet eight inches tall. His father was six
two. That's a difference of six inches. It's a very awkward thing to stab down into the chest of someone who's
half a foot taller than you are.
column6: [NO. 3 jumps up, holding the knife.]
column7: NO. 7: Who says it's easy for me?

column2:
NO. 3: Look, you're not going to be satisfied till you see it again. I'm going to give you a demonstration.
Somebody get up.
column3:
[He looks around the table. NO. 8 stands up and walks toward him. NO. 3 closes the knife and puts it in his
pocket. They stand face to face and look at each other for a moment.]
column4:
NO. 3: Okay. (To NO. 2) Now watch this. I don't want to have to do it again. (He crouches down now until he is
quite a bit shorter than NO. 8) Is that six inches?
column5: NO. 12: That's more than six inches.
column6: NO. 3: That's what I mean. That's the whole case.
column7: NO. 3: Okay, let it be more.

column2:
[He reaches into his pocket and takes out the knife. He flicks it open, changes its position in his hand, and holds
the knife aloft, ready to stab. He and NO. 8 look steadily into each other's eyes. Then he stabs downward,
hard.]
column3: NO. 2: (shouting). Look out!
column4: [He stops short just as the blade reaches NO. 8's chest. NO. 3 laughs]
column5: NO. 6: That's not funny.
column6: NO. 7: Yeah, let's stick to the subject. (To NO. 5) I want to ask you what made you change your vote.
column7: NO. 5: What's the matter with you?

column2: NO. 3: Now just calm down. Nobody's hurt, are they?
column3: NO. 8: (low). No, nobody's hurt.
column4:
NO. 3: All right. There's your angle. Take a look at it. Down and in. That's how I'd stab a taller man in the
chest, and that's how it was done. Take a look at it and tell me I'm wrong.
column5:
[NO. 2 doesn't answer. NO. 3 looks at him for a moment, then jams the knife into the table and sits down. They
all look at the knife.]
column6:
NO. 6: Down and in. I guess there's no argument.
[NO. 8 picks the knife out of the table and closes it. He flicks it open, and changing its position in his hand,
stabs downward with it.]
column7: FOREMAN: NO. 9?

column2: NO. 8: (to NO. 6). Did you ever stab a man?
column3: NO. 6: Of course not.
column4: NO. 8: (to NO. 3). Did you?
column5: NO. 3: All right, let's not be silly.
column6: NO. 3: (to NO. 8). What are you doing?
column7: NO. 8: Did you?

column2: NO. 3: (loudly). No, I didn't!
column3: NO. 8: Where do you get all your information about how it's done?
column4: NO. 3: What do you mean? It's just common sense.
column5: NO. 8: Have you ever seen a man stabbed?
column6: NO. 4: 1 can't understand a word in here. Why do we all have to talk at once?
column7: NO. 3: (pauses and looks around the room nervously) No.

column2:
NO. 8: All right. I want to ask you something. The boy was an experienced knife fighter. He was even sent to
reform school for knifing someone, isn't that so?
column3: NO. 12: That's right.
column4:
NO. 8: Look at this. (NO.8 closes the knife, flicks it open, and changes the position of the knife so that he can
stab over-handed.) Doesn't it seem like an awkward way to handle a knife?
column5: NO. 3: What are you asking me for?
column6: NO. 5: (to NO. 7). You mean you still don't think there's room for reasonable doubt?
column7: [NO. 8 closes the blade and flicks it open, holds it ready to slash underhanded.]

column2: NO. 5: Wait a minute! What's the matter with me? Give me that.
column3: [He reaches out for the knife.]
column4: NO. 8: Have you ever seen a knife fight?
column5: NO. 5: Yes, I have.
column6: NO. 8: In the movies?
column7: NO. 8: (to NO. 3). Did you?

column2:
NO. 5: In my back yard, on my stoop, in the vacant lot across the street, too many of them. Switch knives came
with the neighborhood where I lived. Funny I didn't think of it before. I guess you try to forget those things.
(Flicking the knife open) Anyone who's ever used a switch knife would never have stabbed downward. You
don't handle a switch knife that way. You use it underhanded.
column3: NO. 8: Then he couldn't have made the kind of wound, which killed his father.
column4: NO. 5: No, he couldn't have. Not if he'd ever had any experience with switch knives.
column5: NO. 3:1 don't believe it.
column6: NO. 10: Neither do 1. You're giving us a lot of mumbo jumbo.
column7: NO. 10: You know it's possible.

column2: NO.8: (to NO. 12). What do you think?
column3: NO. 12: (hesitantly). Well . . . I don't know.
column4: NO. 8: (to NO.7). What about you?
column5:
NO. 7: Listen, I'll tell you something. I'm a little sick of this whole thing already. We're getting nowhere fast.
Let's break it up and go home. I'm changing my vote to not guilty.
column6: NO. 10: All right. Forget it. It don't mean anything.
column7: NO. 3: You're what?

column2: NO. 7: You heard me. I've had enough.
column3: NO. 3: What do you mean; you've had enough? That's no answer.
column4:
NO. 11: (angry). I think perhaps you're right. This is not an answer. (To NO.7) What kind of a man are you?
You have sat here and voted guilty with everyone else because there are some theater tickets burning a hole in
your pocket. Now you have changed your vote for the same reason. I do not think you have the right to play like
this with a man's life. This is an ugly and terrible thing to do.
column5: NO.7: Now wait a minute… you can't talk like that to me.
column6:
NO. 11: (strong). I can talk like that to you! If you want to vote not guilty, then do it because you are convinced
the man is not guilty. If you believe he is guilty, then vote that way. Or don't you have the . . . the . . . guts—the
guts to do what you think is right?
column7: NO. 3: You're what?

column2: NO.7: Now listen....
column3: NO. 11: 1s it guilty or not guilty?
column4: NO. 7: (hesitantly). I told you. Not guilty.
column5: NO. 11: (hard). Why?
column6: NO.7.1 don't have to
column7: NO. 4: The boy admits going out of his house at eight o'clock after being slapped by his father.

column2: NO. 11.You have to! Say it! Why?
column3: [They stare at each other for a long while.]
column4: NO.7: (low) l... don't think . . . he's guilty.
column5:
NO. 8: (fast). I want another vote.
FOREMAN: Okay, there's another vote called for. I guess the quickest way is a show of hands. Anybody
object? (No one does.) All right. All those voting not guilty, raise your hands.
column6:
[Numbers 2, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9, and 11 raise their hands immediately. Then, slowly NO.12 raises his hand. The
foreman looks around the table carefully, and then he too raises his hand. He looks around the table, counting
silently.]
column7:
NO. 8: The old man heard the boy say, "I'm going to kill you," and one second later he heard a body fall. One
second. That's the testimony, right?

column2: FOREMAN: Nine. (The hands go down.) All those voting guilty.
column3: [Numbers 3, 4, and 10 raise their hands.]
column4: FOREMAN:Three. (They lower their hands.) The vote is nine to three in favor of acquittal.
column5:
NO.10: I don't understand you people. How can you believe this kid is innocent? Look, you know how those
people lie. l don't have to tell you. They don't know what the truth is. And lemme tell you, they— (NO.5 gets up
from table, turns his back to it, and goes to window.)—don't need any real big reason to kill someone either.
You know, they get drunk, and bang, someone's lying in the gutter. Nobody's blaming them. That's how they
are. You know what I mean? Violent!
column6: [NO.9 gets up and does the same. He is followed by NO.11]
column7: NO. 8: (to NO. 5). Do you think he lied?

column2:
NO.10: Human life don't mean as much to them as it does to us. Hey, where are you going? Look, these people
are drinking and fighting all the time, and if somebody gets killed, so somebody gets killed. They don't care.
Oh, sure, there are some good things about them, too. Look, I'm the first to say that.
column3: [NO. 8 gets up, and then NO. 2 and NO. 6 follow him to the window.]
column4:
NO.10: I've known a few who were pretty decent, but that's the exception. Most of them; it's like they have no
feelings. They can do anything. What's going on here?
column5: [The foreman gets up and goes to the windows, followed by NO. 7 and NO. 12:]
column6: NO. 8: (calmly) Our fingers. Are you his executioner?
column7:
NO.10:.1'm speaking my piece, and you listen to me! They're no good. There's not a one of ‘em who's any
good. We better watch out. Take it from me. This kid on trial....

column2:
[NO. 3 sits at table toying with the knife, and NO. 4 gets up and starts for the window. All have their backs to
NO.10.]
column3:
NO.10: Well, don't you know about them? Listen to me! What are you doing? I'm trying to tell you
something....
column4: [NO. 4 stands over him as he trails off. There is a dead silence. Then NO. 4 speaks softly.]
column5: NO. 4: I've had enough. If you open your mouth again, I'm going to split your skull.
column6: NO. 9: That's right. Bifocals. She never took them off.
column7:
[NO. 4 stands mere and looks at him. No one moves or speaks. NO. 10 looks at him, then looks down at the
table.]

column2: NO. 10: (softly). I'm only trying to tell you....
column3: [There is a long pause as NO. 4 stares down at NO. 10:]
column4: NO. 4: (to all). All right. Sit down everybody.
column5: [They all move back to their seats. When they are all seated, NO. 4 then sits down.]
column6:
NO. 3: I'm ready to walk into court right now and declare a hung jury. There's no point in this going on any
more.
column7:
NO. 4: (quietly). I still believe the boy is guilty of murder. I'll tell you why. To me, the most damning evidence
was given by the woman across the street who claimed she actually saw the murder committed.

column2: NO. 3: That's right. As far as I'm concerned, that's the most important testimony.
column3: NO. 8: All right. Let's go over her testimony. What exactly did she say?
column4:
NO. 4: I believe I can recount it accurately. She said that she went to bed at about eleven o'clock that night. Her
bed was next to the open window, and she could look out of the window while lying down and see directly into
the window across the street. She tossed and turned for over an hour, unable to fall asleep. Finally she turned
toward the window at about twelve ten and as she looked out, she saw the boy stab his father. As far as I can
see, this is unshakable testimony.
column5: NO. 3: That's what I mean. That's the whole case.
column6: [NO. 4 takes off his eyeglasses and begins to polish them, as they all sit silently watching him.]
column7:
NO. 10: I don't mind telling you this, mister. We don't owe him a thing. He got a fair trial, didn't he? You know
what that trial cost? He's lucky he got it. Look, we're all grownups here. You're not going to tell us that we're
supposed to believe him, knowing what he is. I've lived among 'em all my life. You can't believe a word they
say. You know that.

column2:
NO. 4: (to the jury). Frankly, I don't see how you can vote for acquittal. (To NO. 12) What do you think about
it?
column3: NO. 12: Well . . . maybe . . . there's so much evidence to sift.
column4: NO. 3: What do you mean, maybe? He's absolutely right. You can throw out all the other evidence.
column5: NO. 4: That was my feeling.
column6: NO. 8: I'm sorry for you.
column7: [NO. 2, polishing his glasses, squints at clock ,but can' t see it. NO. 6 watches him closely.]

column2: NO. 2: What time is it?
column3: NO. 11: Ten minutes of six.
column4: NO. 2: It's late. You don't suppose they'd let us go home and finish it in the morning. I've got a kid with mumps.
column5: NO. 5: Not a chance.
column6: FOREMAN: NO. 10?
column7: NO. 6: (to NO. 2). Pardon me. Can't you see the clock without your glasses?

column2: NO. 2: Not clearly. Why?
column3:
NO. 6: Oh, I don't know. Look, this may be a dumb thought, but what do you do when you wake up at night and
want to know what time it is?
column4: NO. 2: What do you mean? I put on my glasses and look at the clock.
column5: NO. 6: You don't wear them to bed.
column6: NO. 2: Of course not. NO. one wears eyeglasses to bed.
column7: NO. 8: Does anyone think there still is not a reasonable doubt?

column2: NO. 12: What's all this for?
column3: NO. 6: Well, I was thinking. You know the woman who testified that she saw the killing wears glasses.
column4: NO. 3: So does my grandmother. So what?
column5: NO. 8: Your grandmother isn't a murder witness.
column6: NO. 6: Look, stop me if I'm wrong. This woman wouldn't wear her eyeglasses to bed, would she?
column7: NO. 8: I don't know. It doesn't sound right to me.

column2: FOREMAN: Wait a minute! Did she wear glasses at all? I don't remember.
column3:
NO. 11: (excited). Of course she did! The woman wore bifocals. I remember this very clearly. They looked
quite strong.
column4: NO. 9: That's right. Bifocals. She never took them off.
column5: NO. 4: She did wear glasses. Funny. I never thought of it.
column6:
NO. 8: Listen, she wasn't wearing them in bed. That's for sure. She testified that in the midst of her tossing and
turning she rolled over and looked casually out the window. The murder was taking place as she looked out, and
the lights went out a split second later. She couldn't have had time to put on her glasses. Now maybe she
honestly thought she saw the boy kill his father. I say that she saw only a blur.
column7:
NO. 8: An el takes ten seconds to pass a given point or two seconds per car. That el had been going by the old
man's window for at least six seconds and maybe more, before the body fell, according to the woman. The old
man would have had to hear the boy say, "I'm going to kill you," while the front of the el was roaring past his
nose. It's not possible that he could nave heard it.

column2: NO. 3: How do you know what she saw? Maybe she's far-sighted.
column3: [He looks around. No one answers.]
column4: NO. 3: (loudly). How does he know all these things?
column5: [There is silence.]
column6: NO. 8: Or punched.
column7: NO. 8: Does anyone think there still is not a reasonable doubt?

column2: [He looks around the room, then squarely at NO. 10. NO. 10 looks down and shakes his head no]
column3: NO. 3: (loudly). I think he's guilty!
column4: NO. 8: (calmly). Does anyone else?
column5: NO. 4: (quietly). No. I'm convinced.
column6: NO. 4: (to NO. 8). This knife is a pretty strong piece of evidence, don't you agree?
column7: NO. 8: (to NO. 3). You're alone.

column2: NO. 3: I don't care whether I'm alone or not! I have a right.
column3:
NO. 8: You have a right.
[There is a pause. They all look at NO. 3:]
column4: NO. 3: Well, I told you I think the kid's guilty. What else do you want?
column5: NO. 8: Your arguments.
column6: [They all look at NO. 3:]
column7: NO. 8: Where do you get all your information about how it's done?

column2: NO. 3: I gave you my arguments.
column3: NO. 8: We're not convinced. We're waiting to hear them again. We have time.
column4: [NO. 3 runs to NO. 4 and grabs his arm.]
column5:
NO. 3: (pleading). Listen. What's the matter with you? You're the guy. You made all the arguments. You can't
turn now. A guilty man's gonna be walking the streets. A murderer. He's got to die! Stay with me.
column6: NO. 4: I'm sorry. There's a reasonable doubt in my mind.
column7: NO. 5: Not a chance.

column2: NO. 8: We're waiting.
column3: [NO. 3 turns violently on him.]
column4:
NO. 3: (shouting). Well, you're not going to intimidate me! (They all look at NO. 3.) I'm entitled to my opinion!
(No one answers him.) It's gonna be a hung jury! That's it!
column5:
NO. 8: There's nothing we can do about that, except hope that some night, maybe in a few months, you'll get
some sleep.
column6: NO. 12: What's all this for?
column7: NO. 5: You're all alone.

column2: MR. MARTIN: I knew that third wife, if I'm not mistaken. She ate chicken sitting on a hornet's nest.
column3: FIRE CHIEF: It's not the same one.
column4: MRS. SMITH: Shh!
column5: FIRE CHIEF: As I was saying. ..whose third wife was the daughter of the best midwife in the region and who, earlyleft a widow...
column6: MR. SMITH: Like my wife.
column7: FIRE CHIEF: Oh, not even that. A straw fire and a little heartburn.

column2: MRS. SMITH: His britches?MR.MARTIN: No his bridge game.
column3: FIRE CHIEF: And had married an oyster woman, whose father had a brother, mayor of a small town, who had taken ashis wife a blonde schoolteacher, whose cousin, a fly fisherman....
column4: MR. MARTIN: A fly by night?
column5: FIRE CHIEF: Had married another blonde schoolteacher, named Marie, too, whose brother was married to anotherMarie, also a blonde schoolteacher. ..
column6: MR. MARTIN [to the Fire Chief]: But the third time--it was not you who rang?
column7: MR. SMITH: Since she's blonde, she must be Marie.

column2: MRS. SMITH: A curious story. Almost unbelievable.
column3: MR. MARTIN: If you catch a cold, you should get yourself a colt.
column4: MR. SMITH: It's a useless precaution, but absolutely necessary.
column5: MRS. MARTIN: Excuse me, Mr. Fire Chief, but I did not follow your story very well. At the end, when we got to thegrandmother of the priest, I got mixed up.
column6: MR. SMITH: One always gets mixed up in the hands of a priest.
column7: FIRE CHIEF: There's nothing doing there. He is insured against fires.

column2: FIRE CHIEF: Ah, I don't know whether I'll be able to. I'm on official business. It depends on what time it is.
column3: MRS. SMITH: We don't have the time, here.
column4: FIRE CHIEF: But the clock?
column5: MR. SMITH: It runs badly. It is contradictory, and always indicates the opposite of what the hour really is.[Enter Mary.]
column6: MARY: I'm so glad to see you again. ..at last!MR. AND MRS. SMITH: Oh!
column7: MARY: Madam... sir. ..

column2: MR. SMITH: What have you come in here for?
column3: MARY: I hope, madam and sir will excuse me ...and these ladies and gentlemen too. ..I would like. ..I would like ...totell you a story, myself.
column4: MRS. MARTIN: What is she saying?
column5: MR. MARTIN: I believe that our friends' maid is going crazy ...she wants to tell us a story, too.   .
column6: MR. MARTIN: That's because I wasn't there yet. ..
column7: FIRE CHIEF: Who does she think she is? [He looks at her.] Oh!

column2: MR. SMITH: This is really uncalled for, Mary. ..
column3: FIRE CHIEF: Oh! But it is she! Incredible!
column4: MR. SMITH: And you?
column5: MARY: Incredible! Here!
column6: MRS. SMITH: What does all this mean?
column7: MR. SMITH: Goodness, someone is ringing.

column2: FIRE CHIEF: And how![Mary throws herself on the neck of the Fire Chief.]
column3: MARY: I'm so glad to see you again. ..at last!MR. AND MRS. SMITH: Oh!
column4: MR. SMITH: This is too much, here, in our home, in the suburbs of London.
column5: MRS. SMITH: It's not proper! ...
column6: FIRE CHIEF: It was she who extinguished my first fires.
column7: MRS. SMITH: A curious story. Almost unbelievable.

column2: MR. MARTIN: If that is the case. ..dear friends. ..these emotions are understandable, human, honorable...
column3: MRS. MARTIN: All that is human is honorable.
column4: MRS. SMITH: Even so, I don't like to see it ...here among us...
column5: MR. SMITH: She's not been properly brought up. ..
column6: MR. MARTIN: And yet there’s a certain warmth in those lines…
column7: FIRE CHIEF: Oh, you have too many prejudices.

column2: MR. MARTIN: Even if she can sometimes be a rather good detective.
column3: FIRE CHIEF: Let me go.
column4: MARY: Don't be upset! ...They're not so bad really.
column5: MR. SMITH: Hm. ..hm ...you two are very touching, but at the same time, a little. ..a little. ..
column6: MR. MARTIN: Yes, that's exactly the word.
column7: MR. SMITH: He's right.

column2: MR. MARTIN: There is a native British modesty-forgive me for attempting, yet again, to define my thought-notunderstood by foreigners, even by specialists, thanks to which, if I may thus express myself...of course, I don't mean torefer to you...
column3: MARY: I was going to tell you...
column4: MR. SMITH: Don't tell us anything...
column5: MARY: Oh yes!
column6: MRS. SMITH: Go, my little Mary, go quietly to the kitchen and read your poems before the mirror…
column7: MRS. SMITH: It was in all the papers.

column2: MRS. MARTIN: This morning when you looked at yourself in the mirror you didn't see yourself.
column3: MR. MARTIN: That's because I wasn't there yet. ..
column4: MARY: All the same, I could, perhaps, recite a little poem for you.
column5: MRS. SMITH: My little Mary, you are frightfully obstinate.
column6: MARY: I'm going to recite a poem, then, is that agreed? It is a poem entitled "The Fire" in honor of the Fire Chief:                                                      The Fire                                       The polypoids were burning in the wood                                                 A stone caught fire                                                The castle caught fire                                                The forest caught fire                                                The men caught fire                                               The women caught fire                                                The birds caught fire                                                 The fish caught fire                                                The water caught fire                                                 The sky caught fire                                                The ashes caught fire                                               The smoke caught fire                                                 The fire caught fire                                               Everything caught fire![She recites the poem while the Smiths are pushing her offstage]
column7: MRS. SMITH: I don't know enough Spanish to make myself understood.*In English in the original.— Translator's note.

column2: MR. MARTIN: And yet there’s a certain warmth in those lines…
column3: FIRE CHIEF: I thought it was marvelous.
column4: MRS. SMITH: All the same….
column5: MR. SMITH: You’re exaggerating….
column6: FIRE CHIEF: Just a minute …. I admit….all this is very subjective….but this is my conception of the world. Myworld. My dream. My ideal….And now this reminds me that I must leave. Since you don’t have the time here, I musttell you that in exactly three-quarters of an hour and sixteen minutes, I’m having a fire at the other end of the city.Consequently, I must hurry. Even though it will be quite unimportant.
column7: FIRE CHIEF: I can't do that either. He's not English. He's only been naturalized. And naturalized citizens have theright to have houses, but not the right to have them put out if they're burning.

column2: FIRE CHIEF: Oh, not even that. A straw fire and a little heartburn.
column3: MR. SMITH: Well, we’re sorry to see you go.MRS SMITH: You have been very entertaining.
column4: MRS. MARTIN: Thanks to you, we have passed a truly Cartesian quarter of an hour.
column5: FIRE CHIEF [moving towards the door, then stopping]: Speaking of that----the bald soprano? [General silence,embarrassment.]
column6: MR. SMITH: I've been goosed.

column4: POZZO:Stand back! (Vladimir and Estragon move away from Lucky. Pozzo jerks the rope.Lucky looks at Pozzo.) Think, pig! (Pause. Lucky begins to dance.) Stop! (Luckystops.) Forward! (Lucky advances.) Stop! (Lucky stops.) Think!Silence.
column5: LUCKY:On the other hand with regard to—
column6: VLADIMIR:I don't understand.
column7: POZZO:Stop! (Lucky stops.) Back! (Lucky moves back.) Stop! (Lucky stops.) Turn! (Luckyturns towards auditorium.) Think!During Lucky's tirade the others react as follows.1) Vladimir and Estragon all attention, Pozzo dejected and disgusted.2) Vladimir and Estragon begin to protest, Pozzo's sufferings increase.3) Vladimir and Estragon attentive again, Pozzo more and more agitated andgroaning.4) Vladimir and Estragon protest violently. Pozzo jumps up, pulls on the rope.General outcry. Lucky pulls on the rope, staggers, shouts his text. All three throwthemselves on Lucky who struggles and shouts his text.

column2: POZZO:His hat!Vladimir seizes Lucky's hat. Silence of Lucky. He falls. Silence. Panting of thevictors.
column3: ESTRAGON:Avenged!Vladimir examines the hat, peers inside it.
column4: POZZO:Give me that! (He snatches the hat from Vladimir, throws it on the ground,tramples on it.) There's an end to his thinking!
column5: VLADIMIR:But will he be able to walk?
column6: POZZO:The road is free to all.
column7: POZZO:Walk or crawl! (He kicks Lucky.) Up pig!

column2: VLADIMIR:You'll kill him.
column3: POZZO:Up scum! (He jerks the rope.) Help me!
column4: VLADIMIR:How?
column5: POZZO:Raise him up!Vladimir and Estragon hoist Lucky to his feet, support him an instant, then let himgo. He falls.
column6: VLADIMIR:(advancing with short, stiff strides, legs wide apart). I'm beginning to come roundto that opinion. All my life I've tried to put it from me, saying Vladimir, bereasonable, you haven't yet tried everything. And I resumed the struggle. (Hebroods, musing on the struggle. Turning to Estragon.) So there you are again.
column7: ESTRAGON:He's doing it on purpose!

column2: ESTRAGON:To hell with him!
column3: VLADIMIR:Come on, once more.
column4: ESTRAGON:What does he take us for?They raise Lucky, hold him up.
column5: POZZO:Don't let him go! (Vladimir and Estragon totter.) Don't move! (Pozzo fetches bagand basket and brings them towards Lucky.) Hold him tight! (He puts the bag inLucky's hand. Lucky drops it immediately.) Don't let him go! (He puts back thebag in Lucky's hand. Gradually, at the feel of the bag, Lucky recovers his sensesand his fingers finally close round the handle.) Hold him tight! (As before withbasket.) #Now! You can let him go. (Vladimir and Estragon move away from Lucky whototters, reels, sags, but succeeds in remaining on his feet, bag and basket in hishands. Pozzo steps back, cracks his whip.) Forward! (Lucky totters forward.)Back! (Lucky totters back.) Turn! (Lucky turns.) Done it! He can walk. (Turningto Vladimir and Estragon.) Thank you, gentlemen, and let me . . . (he fumbles inhis pockets) . . . let me wish you . . . (fumbles) . . . wish you . . . (fumbles) . . . whathave I done with my watch? (Fumbles.) A genuine half-hunter, gentlemen, withdeadbeat escapement! (Sobbing.) Twas my granpa gave it to me! (He searches onthe ground, Vladimir and Estragon likewise. Pozzo turns over with his foot theremains of Lucky's hat.) Well now isn't that just—
column6: VLADIMIR:You're being asked a question.
column7: VLADIMIR:Perhaps it's in your fob.

column2: VLADIMIR:Silence!All listen, bent double. #
column3: ESTRAGON:I hear something.
column4: POZZO:Where?
column5: VLADIMIR:It's the heart.
column6: POZZO:(disappointed). Damnation!
column7: VLADIMIR:What an idea!

column2: ESTRAGON:Perhaps it has stopped.They straighten up.
column3: POZZO:Which of you smells so bad?
column4: ESTRAGON:He has stinking breath and I have stinking feet.
column5: POZZO:I must go.
column6: ESTRAGON:Good idea.
column7: ESTRAGON:And your half-hunter?

column2: ESTRAGON:Then adieu.
column3: POZZO:Adieu.
column4: VLADIMIR:Adieu.
column5: POZZO:Adieu.Silence. No one moves.
column6: VLADIMIR:Come in? On our hands and knees.
column7: VLADIMIR:Adieu.

column2: ESTRAGON:Adieu.Silence.POZZO:And thank you.
column3: VLADIMIR:Thank you.
column4: POZZO:Not at all.
column5: ESTRAGON:Yes yes.
column6: POZZO:No no.
column7: VLADIMIR:He said by the tree. (They look at the tree.) Do you see any others?

column2: ESTRAGON:No no.Silence.
column3: POZZO:I don't seem to be able . . . (long hesitation) . . . to depart.
column4: ESTRAGON:Such is life.Pozzo turns, moves away from Lucky towards the wings, paying out the rope as hegoes.
column5: VLADIMIR:You're going the wrong way.
column6: POZZO:I need a running start. (Having come to the end of the rope, i.e., off stage, hestops, turns and cries.) Stand back! (Vladimir and Estragon stand back, looktowards Pozzo. Crack of whip.) On! On!
column7: VLADIMIR:I'm glad to see you back. I thought you were gone forever.

column2: VLADIMIR:On!Lucky moves off.
column3: POZZO:Faster! (He appears, crosses the stage preceded by Lucky. Vladimir and Estragonwave their hats. Exit Lucky.) On! On! (On the point of disappearing in his turn hestops and turns. The rope tautens. Noise of Lucky falling off.) Stool! (Vladimirfetches stool and gives it to Pozzo who throws it to Lucky.) Adieu!
column4: VLADIMIR and ESTRAGON:(waving). Adieu! Adieu!
column5: POZZO:Up! Pig! (Noise of Lucky getting up.) On! (Exit Pozzo.) Faster! On! Adieu! Pig!Yip! Adieu!Long silence.
column6: VLADIMIR:You're my only hope.
column7: VLADIMIR:That passed the time.

column2: VLADIMIR:Yes, but not so rapidly.Pause.
column3: ESTRAGON:What do we do now?
column4: VLADIMIR:I don't know.
column5: ESTRAGON:Let's go.
column6: VLADIMIR:We can't.
column7: ESTRAGON:Why it's absolutely certain.

column2: VLADIMIR:We're waiting for Godot.
column3: ESTRAGON:(despairingly). Ah!Pause.
column4: VLADIMIR:How they've changed!
column5: ESTRAGON:Who?
column6: VLADIMIR:Those two.
column7: ESTRAGON:He said Godot.

column2: VLADIMIR:Haven't they?
column3: ESTRAGON:What?
column4: VLADIMIR:Changed.
column5: ESTRAGON:Very likely. They all change. Only we can't.
column6: POZZO:But that would surprise me.
column7: VLADIMIR:Likely! It's certain. Didn't you see them?

column2: VLADIMIR:Yes you do know them.
column3: ESTRAGON:No I don't know them.
column4: VLADIMIR:We know them, I tell you. You forget everything. (Pause. To himself.) Unlessthey're not the same . . .ESTRAGON:Why didn't they recognize us then?
column5: VLADIMIR:That means nothing. I too pretended not to recognize them. And then nobody everrecognizes us.
column6: ESTRAGON:Forget it. What we need– Ow! (Vladimir does not react.) Ow!
column7: ESTRAGON:What?

column2: ESTRAGON:Didi! It's the other foot!He goes hobbling towards the mound.
column3: VLADIMIR:Unless they're not the same . . .
column4: BOY:(off). Mister!Estragon halts. Both look towards the voice.
column5: ESTRAGON:Off we go again.
column6: POZZO:You are severe. (To Vladimir.) What age are you, if it's not a rude question?(Silence.) Sixty? Seventy? (To Estragon.) What age would you say he was?
column7: VLADIMIR:Approach, my child.Enter Boy, timidly. He halts.

column2: VLADIMIR:Yes.
column3: ESTRAGON:What do you want?
column4: VLADIMIR:Approach!The Boy does not move.
column5: ESTRAGON:(forcibly). Approach when you're told, can't you?The Boy advances timidly, halts.
column6: VLADIMIR:From a bough? (They go towards the tree.) I wouldn't trust it.
column7: VLADIMIR:What is it?

column2: VLADIMIR:Obviously . . . (Pause.) Approach.
column3: ESTRAGON:(violently). Will you approach! (The Boy advances timidly.) What kept you solate?
column4: VLADIMIR:You have a message from Mr. Godot?
column5: BOY:Yes Sir.
column6: VLADIMIR:Well, what is it?
column7: ESTRAGON:That would be too bad, really too bad. (Pause.) Wouldn't it, Didi, be really toobad? (Pause.) When you think of the beauty of the way. (Pause.) And thegoodness of the wayfarers. (Pause. Wheedling.) Wouldn't it, Didi?

column2: VLADIMIR:(to Estragon). Let him alone.
column3: ESTRAGON:(violently). You let me alone. (Advancing, to the Boy.) Do you know what time itis?
column4: BOY:(recoiling). It's not my fault, Sir.
column5: ESTRAGON:And whose is it? Mine?
column6: BOY:I was afraid, Sir.
column7: ESTRAGON:It's inevitable.

column2: VLADIMIR:I know what it is, he was afraid of the others.
column3: ESTRAGON:How long have you been here?
column4: BOY:A good while, Sir.
column5: VLADIMIR:You were afraid of the whip?
column6: BOY:Yes Sir.
column7: VLADIMIR:But to whom? By whom?

column2: BOY:Yes Sir.
column3: VLADIMIR:The two big men.
column4: BOY:Yes Sir.
column5: VLADIMIR:Do you know them?
column6: ESTRAGON:Repented what?
column7: BOY:No Sir.

column2: BOY:Yes Sir.
column3: ESTRAGON:That's all a pack of lies. (Shaking the Boy by the arm.) Tell us the truth!
column4: BOY:(trembling). But it is the truth, Sir!
column5: VLADIMIR:Will you let him alone! What's the matter with you? #(Estragon releases the Boy, moves away, covering his face with his hands.Vladimir and the Boy observe him. Estragon drops his hands. His face isconvulsed.) What's the matter with you?
column6: ESTRAGON:I'm unhappy.
column7: VLADIMIR:Try and walk.Estragon takes a few limping steps, stops before Lucky and spits on him, thengoes and sits down on the mound.

column2: ESTRAGON:I'd forgotten.
column3: VLADIMIR:Extraordinary the tricks that memory plays! (Estragon tries to speak, renounces,limps to his place, sits down and begins to take off his boots. To Boy.) Well?
column4: BOY:Mr. Godot—
column5: VLADIMIR:I've seen you before, haven't I?
column6: VLADIMIR:He's about to speak.Estragon goes over beside Vladimir. Motionless, side by side, they wait.
column7: BOY:I don't know, Sir.

column2: BOY:No Sir.
column3: VLADIMIR:It wasn't you came yesterday?
column4: BOY:No Sir.
column5: VLADIMIR:This is your first time?
column6: VLADIMIR:What?
column7: BOY:Yes Sir.Silence.

column2: BOY:(in a rush). Mr. Godot told me to tell you he won't come this evening but surelytomorrow.Silence.
column3: VLADIMIR:Is that all?
column4: BOY:Yes Sir.Silence.
column5: VLADIMIR:You work for Mr. Godot?
column6: BOY:Yes Sir.
column7: ESTRAGON:Don't let's do anything. It's safer.

column2: BOY:I mind the goats, Sir.
column3: VLADIMIR:Is he good to you?
column4: BOY:Yes Sir.
column5: VLADIMIR:He doesn't beat you?
column6: POZZO:He's not pleased.
column7: BOY:No Sir, not me.

column2: BOY:He beats my brother, Sir.
column3: VLADIMIR:Ah, you have a brother?
column4: BOY:Yes Sir.
column5: VLADIMIR:What does he do?
column6: ESTRAGON:Ah! That's better.He puts the bones in his pocket.
column7: BOY:He minds the sheep, Sir.

column2: BOY:I don't know, Sir.
column3: VLADIMIR:He must be fond of you.
column4: BOY:I don't know, Sir.Silence.
column5: VLADIMIR:Does he give you enough to eat? (The Boy hesitates.) Does he feed you well?
column6: ESTRAGON:Quick! (Pozzo gets up and goes over beside Estragon. Estragon points off.) Look!
column7: BOY:Fairly well, Sir.

column2: BOY:Yes Sir.VLADIMIR:Well?
column3: BOY:I don't know, Sir.
column4: VLADIMIR:You don't know if you're unhappy or not?
column5: BOY:No Sir.
column6: VLADIMIR:You're as bad as myself. (Silence.) Where do you sleep?
column7: VLADIMIR:I don't understand.

column2: VLADIMIR:With your brother?
column3: BOY:Yes Sir.
column4: VLADIMIR:In the hay?
column5: BOY:Yes Sir.Silence.
column6: ESTRAGON:(looking at the neck). I see nothing.
column7: VLADIMIR:All right, you may go.

column2: VLADIMIR:Tell him . . . (he hesitates) . . . tell him you saw us. (Pause.) You did see us, didn'tyou?
column3: BOY:Yes Sir.He steps back, hesitates, turns and exit running. The light suddenly fails. In amoment it is night. The moon rises at back, mounts in the sky, stands still,shedding a pale light on the scene.
column4: VLADIMIR:At last! (Estragon gets up and goes towards Vladimir, a boot in each hand. Heputs them down at edge of stage, straightens and contemplates the moon.) #What are you doing?
column5: ESTRAGON:Pale for weariness.
column6: ESTRAGON:Unforgettable.
column7: VLADIMIR:Eh?

column2: VLADIMIR:Your boots, what are you doing with your boots?
column3: ESTRAGON:(turning to look at the boots). I'm leaving them there. (Pause.) Another will come,just as . . . as . . . as me, but with smaller feet, and they'll make him happy.
column4: VLADIMIR:But you can't go barefoot!
column5: ESTRAGON:Christ did.
column6: VLADIMIR:Christ! What has Christ got to do with it. You're not going to compare yourself toChrist!
column7: VLADIMIR:STOP IT!Exit Vladimir hurriedly. Estragon gets up and follows him as far as the limit ofthe stage. Gestures of Estragon like those of a spectator encouraging a pugilist.Enter Vladimir. He brushes past Estragon, crosses the stage with bowed head.Estragon takes a step towards him, halts.

column2: VLADIMIR:But where he lived it was warm, it was dry!
column3: ESTRAGON:Yes. And they crucified quick.Silence.
column4: VLADIMIR:We've nothing more to do here.
column5: ESTRAGON:Nor anywhere else.
column6: VLADIMIR:How do I know? (They close in on him.) Careful!
column7: VLADIMIR:Ah Gogo, don't go on like that. Tomorrow everything will be better.

column2: VLADIMIR:Did you not hear what the child said?
column3: ESTRAGON:No.
column4: VLADIMIR:He said that Godot was sure to come tomorrow. (Pause.) What do you say to that?
column5: ESTRAGON:Then all we have to do is to wait on here.
column6: VLADIMIR:Are you mad? We must take cover. (He takes Estragon by the arm.) Come on.He draws Estragon after him. Estragon yields, then resists. They halt.
column7: ESTRAGON:What is it?

column2: VLADIMIR:Come on. It's cold.He draws Estragon after him. As before.
column3: ESTRAGON:Remind me to bring a bit of rope tomorrow.
column4: VLADIMIR:Yes. Come on.He draws him after him. As before.
column5: ESTRAGON:How long have we been together all the time now?
column6: VLADIMIR:Let's wait till we know exactly how we stand.
column7: VLADIMIR:I don't know. Fifty years maybe.

column2: VLADIMIR:We were grape harvesting.
column3: ESTRAGON:You fished me out.
column4: VLADIMIR:That's all dead and buried.
column5: ESTRAGON:My clothes dried in the sun.
column6: VLADIMIR:We'll come back tomorrow.
column7: VLADIMIR:There's no good harking back on that. Come on.He draws him after him. As before.

column2: VLADIMIR:I'm cold!
column3: ESTRAGON:Wait! (He moves away from Vladimir.) I sometimes wonder if we wouldn't havebeen better off alone, each one for himself. (He crosses the stage and sits down onthe mound.) We weren't made for the same road.
column4: VLADIMIR:(without anger). It's not certain.
column5: ESTRAGON:No, nothing is certain.Vladimir slowly crosses the stage and sits down beside Estragon. #
column6: ESTRAGON:Pah! The wind in the reeds.
column7: VLADIMIR:We can still part, if you think it would be better.
